results.name: Once 1, once 0, repeat, twice 1, twice 0, repeat, thrice 1, thrice 0... and so on.
comment: The definition is that of a linear sequence. Equivalently, define a (0,1) infinite lower triangular matrix T(n,k) (0 <= k <= n) by T(n,k) = 1 if k >= n/2, 0 otherwise, and read it by rows. The triangle T begins:
...  The matrix T is used in A168508. [Comment revised by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Dec 05 2020]
Also, square array A read by antidiagonals upwards: A(n,k) = 1 if k >= n, 0 otherwise.
For n >= 1, T(n,k) = number of partitions of n into k parts of sizes 1 or 2. - _Nicolae Boicu_, Aug 23 2018
link: Boris Putievskiy, Transformations (of) Integer Sequences And Pairing Functions, arXiv:1212.2732 [math.CO], 2012.
formula: G.f.: 1/[(1-xy)(1-y)]. k-th row of array: x^(k-1)/(1-x).
T(n, k) = if(binomial(k, n-k)>0, 1, 0). - _Paul Barry_, Aug 23 2005
example: The array A (on the left) and the triangle T of its antidiagonals (on the right):
mathematica: rows = 15; A = Array[If[#1 <= #2, 1, 0]&, {rows, rows}]; Table[A[[i-j+1, j]], {i, 1, rows}, {j, 1, i}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, May 04 2017 *)
xref: Row sums of T (and antidiagonal sums of A) are A008619.
